title: GRASP - Emergence of Cognitive Grasping through Introspection, Emulation and Surprise

author: Danica Kragić, School of Computer Science and Communication, KTH - Royal Institute of Technology

segmentation: Thank you, Michelle.
So thanks to those that actually came back to listen to Grossman Temse presentation.
And I have to say that I'm really, really happy because yesterday we had a final review Integrous project here in Vienna and everything went very well.
So I'm just going to show you some of the results of the research that we have been doing during the past four years.
Just to give you a little bit idea of grass, we are still for two months more nine partners, 8 academic partners and industry ottobock prosthesis, developer from here local in Vienna.
And most of the people have background in robotics.
But then we also have some psychologists so.
The project round for four years and here is web page if you would like to see or download some of our publications, but then also some of the software that I will be presenting during my talk.
Now with that out and planned this project approximately 5 years back and we sat down, we felt that grasping an object manipulation was an unsolved problem.
Although people in the robotics community have dealt with it for two or three decades at that point.
We felt that grasping well studied a lot as a control problem and we knew a lot about how to pose the stability constraints and so on on grasps.
But there were a number of objectives that we wanted to address in this project that we felt were actually open problems in the area.
Theory of grass modeling self and context awareness, curiosity and surprise driven behavior.
Knew grasping strategies and then exploitation for industrial in service markets.
I think that the objectives are as they are stated here.
Quite general and are related to some of the objectives for other projects that have been presented today.
So just going to give you a little bit of taste for what we have accomplished and done during.
Out the past four years.

Of course, grasping can be seen on a very low sensory level as a kind of like reactive behavior, but it can be seen also as a very complex cognitive tasks task, and this is what we tried to address in the project and.

Apart from the really testing and implementing complex grasping behavior in different types of robot systems, you will see some of them we have also spent quite amount of time on trying to understand grasping in humans, although some stuff from haptic control of grasping have been done, we felt that research on Overton covert attention when it comes to grasping.
So where do humans put their eyes?
What are they?
Looking at prior to prior enduring grasping, so this is one of the things that we worked on.
I will show you how we develop the markerless hand tracking system that can be used for also studying human grasping in unstructured environments.
And say a little bit about machine learning methods for comparing different designs of anthropomorphic hands.
That this was something that was very important also for our industrial partner Autobook.
And there are a number of things that are related to multi sensory or sensory based grasping both when it comes to computer vision.

When it comes to haptic control, we have developed some simulator open grasp that is publicly available for download and testing and we have spent quite some time on discussing what would be a good benchmarking task when it comes to grasping.
So I hope that this will also be.
Accepted by the community post to this project.
Now, when it comes to human grasping, this is work of Professor Heiner Deibel from LMU.
There are very many things we can study when it comes to grasping humours, but some of the interesting things that hinder has done with his group is really looked into.
What are we doing with our eyes?
What is that we attending to both overthink and covertly when we are grasping?
And why is that important?
Well, it can give us some.
Insight in how to develop real time or Activision systems for different types of complex robot systems and equip them with the similar or same ability as humans have.
And another thing that was important for this project was our work on.
Let's see if I can do that.
I have had some problems with.
My mouth so the second thing that was really important to us was the ability to track.
Human hands in interaction with objects without the need of putting any markers on the human hand.
This is work from Professor Antonio Sergios from Fort is also here.
You can talk to him and the idea here was that we in order to understand human grasping, grasping is about the interaction between hand an object and the interesting thing in this work.
First, it's completely markerless.
It's real time.
And it also apart from tracking one hand, the recent work of Antonis can also track two hands in interaction with objects.
There are lots of links on the project web page, so I encourage you to go and look both for publications and additional videos of examples of this really nice software.
Now.
The next thing that was also one of the things that we discussed a lot during the four years, is what is a good growth?
How do we define a group growth?
And of course, grasping is not only about putting your fingers around an object and lifting an object is also understanding what and how we should be grasping object for a specific task.
How we can, in the best possible way use, let's say sensory feedback both visual and haptic and also provide some.
Insight in solving the correspondence problem.
So, given that a robot has completely different kinematics of the hand, only three fingers, maybe.
How can we map human grasping at two robots with very different kinematic capabilities and also dynamic ones?
Additional thing that we did was the use and development of different types.
State of the art machine learning methods for comparing human and well different types of anthropomorphic robot hands.
So we really wanted to understand is the level of how anthropomorphic in certain hand design is and this was really interesting.
Again for our industrial partner Autoblok because they are very interested in building hands that look like human hand.
But they cannot actually ate all the joints becausw a prosthetic hand would get very heavy.
So the typical question here is how much to bend fingers?
What should be the spread angle?
How big should the hand be, and where should the Motors be?
So which degrees of freedom should be actuated?
So again, this work is well, hopefully soon publishing transactions on robotics.
So I encourage you to go and search for.
This.

An important thing for us was to also be able to generate a large amount of training or example sequences of grasping that is not only about stability assessment in terms of, you know, estimating friction cones and forces and so on, but it's also for providing dynamic sequences and sensor readings that we can use in different types of machine learning methods, so providing a good model for tactile feedback.
A good model for change in weight, for example, of the object when it's being manipulated and also have a good simulator for providing example visual feed.
Back in relation to that, we have also defined or design a number of benchmarking.
Well you can see it as a benchmarking suit, but we have seen some grasping today, but we really wanted to aim high.
So what we set out to do was to actually empty a box full of objects that are just thrown in the box so they are not object nicely standing.
Far away from each other or anything like that, there are no objects that have like only a box shape or only a single color or anything like that so.
What you're seeing here, this is actually the work that has been done year three and this is our mark three, from KIT.
Professor Dillman Slab, and Tommy Mouse words work and then we also have a friends from University in Castillon.
In Spain there dual arm robot and what we also demonstrated today.
Marcus people visited your lab.
I think that the setup was also a little bit more complex, so the idea is like take any 1015 objects, just throw them in a box.
Put it in front of the robot and ask the robot to empty the box.
And so we succeeded in that yesterday, together with three reviewers that we had for the project.
We basically use them and told them just put objects in the boxes as you want.
And that was a real nice thing, but something that we all need to think about.
This is not only about vision, this is about four Storke.
This is about haptic feedback and I don't know if you can see it from this sequence is without me saying the robots in this case are doing so called blind grasping.
So we wanted to try here.
3 is how can the robot succeed to do grasping without any visual feedback?
So how can the robot use?
Haptic and force torque control to feel where the objects are and try to empty the box completely blind.
And then yesterday we demonstrated the integration of visual and haptic feedback.
So For more information about how we did it, just please visit our web.
Now the final thing that I would like to also address is that grasping in general is task related, so we grasp things because we want to do something with them.
Grasping a Cup for drinking is very different from or it may be different from grasping Cup for putting it in a dishwasher or giving it to somebody and so on.
This is why in a few slides back I have the question what is a good grasp?
Now in this work we are in this project we also developed a probabilistic system.
For task oriented grasping that can be used for, let me see if I can again find my mouse.
Where a robot can.
Grasp an object and manipulate it based on the task it is given so.
Let me see if this place.
Yeah again you will see other humanoid robot or not hour but Professor domers humanoid robot armor and also dual arm robot from Castillon.
Anne.
Can I just remove that?
No, that is the wrong button.
Well, it should disappear after some time, right?
So the idea here is that the robot grasps an object.
An arbitrary object is in such a way that it can apply a certain action to it, so such As for example, if it wants to play with the car.
Then a this type of grasp needs to be applied because it allows translating the car on the surface it is placed on.
The number of different examples of which tasks we consider.
Now there is many different things going on here.
There is some state of the art vision research on object categorization, so that is doing categorization of different objects real time segmentation.
Grasping points election.
Registration of pointclouds.
Name it.
There are yeah, so this is example of categorisation.
For categorization we're using 2D and integration of 2D and 3D features and.
We can do categorization, so this is not object recognition.
This is categorization.
We can do that from very poor and very noisy visual feedback.
And the red point on the top was grasping point that is best for this category.
This task and.
Yeah, so the white.
White white line around the object is the actual segmentation, so it's segmenting the system is segmenting objects from the background in real time.
So let me see.
The couple of examples also on our YouTube channel that we have we have on the web so I'll stop here.
Also OK, so this is also an example from.
The simulator I know it.
Where the simulator can be used as introspection engine and also it can be used for emulation.
It gives an idea to the robot how well the robot can in its mind.
Basically test different types of graphs doesn't for stability test them for.
Collision and so on.
And once the good grasp is found, it can be executed and stored in the robot's memory and then used in the next.
In the next session.
OK so I can take questions if there are any.
At this point.
